title-group.article-title: Comment on 3PL IRT Adjustment for Guessing

author-notes.corresp: Gregory Camilli, School of Education, UCB 249, University of Colorado at Boulder, CO 80309, USA Email: g.camilli@colorado.edu

abstract.p: Guessing behavior is an issue discussed widely with regard to multiple choice tests. Its primary effect is on number-correct scores for examinees at lower levels of proficiency. This is a systematic error or bias, which increases observed test scores. Guessing also can inflate random error variance. Correction or adjustment for guessing formulas has been applied to address some of these issues. The purpose of this research comment is to draw attention to the adjustment for guessing implicit in the three-parameter logistic item response theory model. Potential equity issues also arise with respect to this adjustment.

sec.title: Introduction and Purpose
sec.p: The correction for guessing has a long and lively history in the field of educational measurement. Since its inception, significant controversy has existed regarding its use and its consequences,1 though it continues to be used in some major testing programs (e.g., both the SAT Reasoning and the SAT Subject Matter tests use the classical correction for guessing2). Item response theory (IRT) is a frequent choice to scale test items in the presence of guessing, and it could be argued that IRT technology should be preferred to classical test theory. However, although the three-parameter logistic (3PL) model implicitly adjusts for a guessing (or pseudo-guessing as some prefer), it is not until this correction is translated into an examinee’s item response pattern that the comparison between IRT and classical test theory is demonstrated. Birnbaum (1968) showed how optimal scoring weights can be obtained from the 3PL model, and thus created the link to the observed score metric. Yet, the implications of this link have not been fully appreciated.

It might be surmised that if a correction in the true-score metric can be derived from the 3PL model, then one should just use the latent proficiency of the 3PL model because it also embodies the correction. However, the nature of the correction cannot be clearly understood in the latent metric. It is by showing how a 3PL correction would be devised in the observed metric that clarifies the impact of guessing (i.e., the c parameter) on ability estimation. In fact, some would find this correction objectionable if it were fully understood.

In classical test theory, a formula score is a simple linear transformation of the number-correct score in the absence of omitted responses. Classical measures of reliability and validity are invariant under such a linear transformation. Yet empirically, the classical correction has been found to increase to some degree both reliability and validity coefficients. As elaborated in the following, there is no contradiction: Increases in these indices of test quality result from changing examinee behavior during test administration. Thus, the mechanism of the classical formula, when adequately communicated to test takers, is psychological rather than statistical. As shall be seen below, this is not the case with IRT-based adjustments. For this reason, the classical method can be understood as providing an a priori correction stemming from test-taking behavior, whereas scoring procedures that change the rank order of examinees (as determined by the number-correct score) provide a posteriori corrections. The focus of this article is on the latter.

In the remainder of the article, a brief literature review on corrections for guessing is given initially. This review summarizes select research on the effects of a priori corrections for guessing, but several IRT modeling approaches are given some treatment. Then correction for guessing is treated from the perspective of classical test theory, followed by the perspective of IRT in the framework of the 3PL model. Specifically, an understanding is developed of how IRT proficiency is mathematically defined in the presence of nonzero c parameters. One conclusion to the conceptual component of this investigation is that in 3PL-proficiency estimates, either in the observed score or the latent metric, a penalty is applied to correct answers that are unlikely in terms of person and item parameters, whereas in the classical correction, a penalty is commonly thought to be applied to incorrect answers.

sec.title: Select Literature Review
sec.p: Multiple choice (MC) is the most common type of item format because of typically (but not necessarily) easier development and scoring. Typically, only one option is correct for each item. Each item score (0 = wrong, 1 = right) is then equally weighted and summed to a total, which is referred to as the number-correct score. To counteract guessing, some testing programs use a statistical adjustment to number-correct scores. Accordingly, examinees are informed in advance of test administration that for each incorrect answer the quantity 1/(k − 1) will be subtracted from their score, where k is the number of options for the MC item. If examinees responded according to a rationale decision-making model, they would omit their response to any item for which they were completely unsure of the answer. The deceptively simple phrase formula scoring or negative marking are most often used to describe this practice.

If examinees are encouraged to answer as many questions as possible,3 regardless of whether they know an answer, then guessing behavior is likely to increase, possibly introducing both random error variance and positive bias (Rowley & Traub, 1977). Encouraging students to guess can lead to examinees losing capacity to self-evaluate (Abu-Sayf, 1979; Kurz, 1999) and thus open the door for a number of undesirable testwiseness (or even irrational) behaviors that affect score validity (Chevalier, 1998). The argument for formula scoring is that students who understand its effects will minimize guessing, and in turn, irrelevant test-score variance and bias associated with guessing will be reduced. Accordingly, formula scoring is more accurately described as a method for discouraging, rather than correcting, guessing. More than three decades of research has shown that formula scores tend to have slightly higher reliabilities and validities than uncorrected scores (Alnabhan, 2002; Burton, 2002; Diamond & Evans, 1973). Ironically, Lord (1975, 1980) suggested that the greatest improvement in score accuracy occurs for lower ability examinees who are least likely to understand the formula-scoring instructions. A large literature exists on testwiseness (e.g., García-Pérez & Frary, 1989; Rogers & Yang, 1996; Sarnaki, 1979) that overlaps with the literature on guessing and scoring, but the focus of this article is on IRT scoring in the 3PL model.

Several arguments against formula scoring have been advanced. One clear drawback has been known for some time: If a student answers an item incorrectly based on confident misinformation, then the “correction” may introduce a downward bias in a student’s score relative to students who guess randomly. This is why “almost all formula-scoring instructions in use today, while advising avoidance of completely blind guessing, do encourage examinees to guess whenever they can eliminate a wrong choice” (Frary, 1988, p. 76). The correction also ignores partial knowledge; examinees are assumed either to know the correct answer or to have no knowledge at all. Yet, partial knowledge can arise in at least two related forms. Some incorrect options may be more off-target than others, or an examinee might choose an option by eliminating one or more incorrect options (Rowley & Traub, 1977). The distinction between partial knowledge and guessing may be particularly difficult with MC questions requiring complex cognitive behaviors such as multistep problem solving.

As noted by Burton (2005) and others, personality factors may affect guessing behavior, and it is generally considered undesirable for response sets such as risk-taking behaviors or testwiseness to affect students’ scores. Burton argued for addressing this concern through the fidelity of the test-taking instructions. However, Avila and Torrubia (2004) found support with a meta-analysis of 19 medical examinations for the hypothesis that extraversion and sensitivity to rewards and punishments can affect the number of incorrect responses even when examinees are aware of formula scoring. Finally, the correction ignores distinctions among correct answers, namely, that given a low level of examinee proficiency, correct responses to difficult questions are less credible than correct responses to easy questions.4

In sum, formula scoring is based on three assumptions: (a) The examinee either knows the correct answer or has no knowledge at all; (b) the examinee will answer the item correctly with this knowledge, or will guess or omit the item; and (c) every incorrect response is randomly guessed by the examinee (Crocker & Algina, 1986; Rowley & Traub, 1977). Formula scores would seem to work best when these assumptions are true (Frary, 1988). Muijtjens, Mameren, Hoogenboom, Evers, and van der Vleuten (1999) provided a useful perspective on these issues. They observed that whereas the number-correct score tends to decrease bias, classical formula scoring tends to increase reliability. Given this trade-off, they preferred the number-correct score, but they also concluded that psychometric and educational criteria should be weighed in choosing a scoring method, and this choice may vary across specific testing contexts. Frary (1988) presented four factors for determining whether to use formula scoring, including the ability of examinees to follow instructions, the additional efforts by examinees in following instructions, the projected increase in reliability and validity, and the extent of potential harm to examinees.

Modern test theory offers several alternatives to the conceptualization of guessing. Informal approaches to IRT analysis have been attempted in which guessers are identified and excluded from the data set before item parameter estimation with a two-parameter logistic (2PL) model (i.e., no c parameter). One more systematic approach is robust estimation as reported by Wainer and Wright (1980). They used a jackknife scheme for estimating proficiency (θ) based on a Rasch model applied to noisy data. (Of course, if the model is misspecified, the jackknife may not give improved estimates.) Accordingly, each item was omitted separately and θ reestimated (to compute jackknife pseudo-values and obtain proficiency estimates). Their results indicated that the jackknife procedure reduced the effects of unusual item responses on Rasch estimates of θ. Some criticisms of this work were given by Dimitrov (2004), who also suggested methods for improving the jackknife approach.

In contrast, one more formal measurement approach to guessing treats examinees as having probabilistic membership in latent classes. Yamamoto (1989) formulated a mixture model in which one group (or latent class) of examinees are random guessers, and a second group responds to an item according to a Rasch model. Xie (2002) found that this mixture model fit better than does a simple Rasch model and, in further simulation work, showed that the mixture model provides more accurate estimates than does the 3PL model of both item and person parameters. In another innovative application, San Martín, del Pino, and De Boeck (2006) started with a 3PL model, but further modeled the so-called ‘guessing’ or ‘c parameter’ as a function of examinee proficiency. They found the c parameters seemed to depend on proficiency for a reading test, but not for a mathematics test, and surmised that partial knowledge plays more of a role in reading, where correctness is less of an all-or-none quality. Wise and DeMars (2006) proposed an IRT model including response time to reduce the effects of guessing and other noise that might arise from low examinee effort. In sum, formal modeling continues to grow with respect to guessing; however, none of the resulting IRT approaches have widespread application.

The second representation of the formula has the interesting implication that a penalty of 1/k is paid for all items, whereas a credit of 1/k is given for all omitted items. For examinees who attempt all items, the penalty is paid, but no credit is provided. Some psychometricians have discouraged the use of the word penalty in describing the mechanism underlying the correction for guessing, instead favoring a phrase such as “encouragement to refrain from completely random guessing” (Frary, 1988).

Duncan and Milton (1978) and Gibbons, Olkin, and Sobel (1979) presented a generalization of the classical guessing procedure in which a test item has more than one correct response and an examinee must identify all correct answers. Duncan (1974) considered the case for MC items with a single correct answer. He proposed a Bayesian procedure to obtain a posterior score distribution. According to Duncan,
The misinformation model postulates that a given examinee has knowledge of the correct response to ρ items . . . and perceives a wrong answer as correct on ω . . . more items. The examinee then has misinformation about ω items. (1974, p. 50)

sec.title: IRT Perspective
sec.p: In this section, the situation is considered in which examinee responses are scored either as correct or incorrect—both incorrect answers and omits receive no credit—which is commonly the case in large-scale assessment programs. Given this assumption, the focus is now on a posteriori correction using IRT technology. in the following, some basic formulae are given as prerequisites to formal development. Frary (1988) cautioned that the classical correction does not result in scores that can be “reasonably taken as approximations of those arising in the absence of guessing” (p. 75). In fact, the authors show that the 3PL IRT model results in a “correction for guessing” that does attempt to approximate a number-correct score in the absence of guessing.

sec.title: IRT Adjustment for Nonzero c Parameters
sec.p: In IRT, the probability of an examinee answering an item correctly depends on the examinee’s ability, item parameters, and item response pattern (Hambleton, Swaminathan, & Rogers, 1991). For MC items scored as either correct or incorrect, the item response pattern is a string of 0s and 1s corresponding to the order of items on a test. For most MC tests, students with very low proficiencies have probabilities greater than zero of answering even the most difficult items. The 3PL model (Birnbaum, 1968) adds the pseudo-chance parameter (to discrimination and difficulty) to remove the effect of random guessing (Waller, 1989). It is an assumption of the IRT-based adjustment in the following that (a) examinees are instructed to provide answers to all questions and (b) omitted items are scored as incorrect.

sec.title: Interpretation
sec.p: As Chiu (2011) explained, as the probability of answering a test item incorrectly increases, the factor ηij in the right side of Equation 17 also increases. Consequently, the credit given for a correct item response decreases. In other words, a higher proficiency examinee will receive more credit for a correct response, especially for a difficult item, than an examinee at a lower level of proficiency. This result is derived directly from the maximum likelihood estimate of θ in the 3PL model. That is, the formula is derived by taking the first derivative of the likelihood function and setting the result to zero, and thus is a shared property both of θ and TC. Whether this is a desirable property of test scoring is a factor that should be taken into account when choosing a scoring model. If the 3PL model is the model of choice, the model-based estimate of θ automatically incorporates the adjustment for guessing.

sec.title: Practical Importance
sec.p: Using the 3PL model, corrections are made on the basis of correct answers. The same logic is evident in maximum likelihood estimation of proficiency, which views with varying degrees of suspicion correct answers to questions that are difficult relative to an examinee’s proficiency. A concern thus arises that a more proficient, as compared with a less proficient, examinee will receive more credit for a correct answer to the same item. This equity issue is implicit in any assessment using 3PL scoring, but the consequences are likely to vary with the purpose of testing, such as summative versus diagnostic assessment. In any event, those who use the 3PL should decide whether 3PL scoring is consistent with the purpose of the assessment.8

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Guessing imparts a kind of unreliability to test score that is different from random measurement error, and this fact could result in statistical bias in analyses using number-correct scores. Adjustments or corrections for guessing are not without problems. These problems are relatively well known for the classical correction, which has an extensive literature. However, there is little research on the implicit adjustment for guessing resulting from the 3PL model, either in terms of reliability or validity, and the equity issue is generally unrecognized. The equity issue can be framed in terms of a simple question: Should two examinees who answer an item correctly be given the same credit, regardless of whether one is more able than the other? There is a simple or single answer to this question, but rather this is an issue for which test developers and users should have some awareness. It should also be emphasized that many testing programs that use the 3PL model do not use 3PL scoring. For these programs (which may use 3PL equating or scaling), the issues raised in this article are not a central concern.

To put the main point of this article more starkly, scoring under the 3PL model does not result in the same amount of credit for a correct response to the identical item by examinees of different ability levels: Each item is not an independent snapshot of proficiency. Rather, information is borrowed from other items when determining the amount of credit given. This phenomenon does not occur for the 1PL or 2PL model. From one point of view, 3PL scoring raises an equity issue because lower proficiency examinees are not afforded full opportunity to benefit from correctly answering more difficult items. From a purely psychometric point of view, however, lower proficiency examinees who answer difficult items correctly are more likely (than more proficient examinees) to have guessed. Thus, 3PL scoring is an interesting testing ground where psychometric and social policies intersect.

Another issue raised in 3PL scoring is whether scores obtained from lower proficiency examinees accurately reflect the domain of test content for more difficult items. Assuming a test is developed according to a matrix of specifications, the proportion of items in each cell of the matrix represents the intended coverage of content and processes. But Equation 18 suggests that the cells may be reweighted for some tests and some groups of examinees. Specifically, suppose a group of examinees with mean and variance is equal to µ, σ2. Encouragement to guess might be explicit in the test-taking instructions; for example, “Try to answer all items.” Encouragement could also be implicit; testwise examinees could infer that if there is no penalty for guessing they would optimize their score by attempting all items.

The situation is more complex than this brief treatment suggests. With number-correct scoring, examinees with confidently held misinformation on a particular item will be at a disadvantage relatively to examinees without any knowledge that prefer to guess randomly. As Burton (2005) noted, confidently held misinformation under number-correct scoring can result in lost opportunities to score by guessing. Thus, relative to other examinees, both number-correct and formula scoring have the potential to penalize students whose answers are based on faulty knowledge or reasoning. However, Angoff and Schrader (1984) conducted a study on formula scoring using actual student data. The results suggested that the classical correction does not necessarily penalize examinees. In addition, though formula scoring is said to ignore partial information, Angoff and Schrader found that more able examinees profited more from guessing in terms of corrected score.
